name: Winter Winds Leaving The Front Yard
description:
Re-mastered and with redundant noise reduction for extra clarity. Original Recording Equipment: MixPre 3 version 2 and two Sennheiser MKH 8020s set 2 feet apart. 

The winter winds leaving the front yard create a symphony of soothing sounds that evoke a sense of tranquility and peace. As the brisk breeze rustles through the bare branches of trees, it produces a gentle whispering sound that is both calming and melodic. The crisp air carries with it the faint scent of pine and snow, adding to the serene atmosphere. Occasionally, there is a soft crunching noise as frost-covered leaves are swept along by the wind, creating a gentle rhythm that lulls one into a state of relaxation. The distant howling of coyotes adds an eerie yet mesmerizing element to the overall auditory experience. Overall, the soundscape created by winter winds leaving the front yard provides a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of everyday life, allowing one to momentarily escape into nature's embrace.

name: Vent - wind (1).wav
description: Wind on the Mont Jerbier de Jonc (Ardeche, France). Used on a film I made the sound and music of :O Voo http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pVrCWCGpKwg

name: Wind2.aif
description:
Heavy gusting Arctic or hurricane winds, whistling, rumbling, chimes and deep synthesized wind instrumentation.
Constructed in LIVE! with Reaktor and Reason.
I created a wind patch in a Reaktor synth called Subharmonic. Layered that with another wind patch made in a synth called Steam Pipe 2. I added a filter kick drum for some mic popping sub effect and put a little grain delay on both. Added pan and level automation.
This was my first submission “Wind1”. To that I added synthesized sounds created with four Malstrom graintable synths in Reason.

name: Wind5.aif
description: I combined my "wind2" sound with "wind4" to create "wind5". Constructed in LIVE! with Reaktor and Reason. all the sounds are synthesized except the wind chimes.

name: Winter Wind Mix
description: I mixed 2 different speeds of the same track together using audactiy. Hope this sounds good!

name: Various Environmental Sounds - Procedurally Generated
description: Completely procedurally generated environmental sounds of rain, bonfire, thunder, wind, crickets and cicadas. Based on various custom made real-time sound generating algorithms in max msp and python.

name: ph 1.2 o2b b10 71.wav
description: A longer synth sound - made with one patch in one take. By adjusting the parameters of oscillators, noise, effects, and filters over the length of the recording you get the sounds of static, distant wind, clicking, distortion. From my Experimental synthesiser sounds sample pack - these sounds are the result of my obsession with creating and experimenting with new synthesised sounds.

name: 21100242 Maren Bohmer, SD 100, Wind Chime OWI.mp3
description: Wind-chime are inharmonic sounds, the sound that wind-chimes produce is satisfying dinging to noisy clanging

name: wind_bells_dog_train.mp3
description: a clear, VERY windy day - good for kites, bad for recording - but then ... let's test my mm-18 wind shield!  Numerous sounds behind the wind.  The main items, in order, are: wind, church bells, things blowing and knocking (periodically throughout), small dog, big dog, church bells, and a diesel locomotive train horn (very delicate, at end - probably about 2 miles away).

name: Howling wind
description:
Howling wind was created by sucking air out of a straw, while the straw was in a ziplock bag and then adding a compressor.

Sound was recorded using Zoom H6 recorder, the microphone that was used was the interchangeable input capsule X/Y microphone, that comes with the recorder. Reaper was used to remove some noise reduction was done using ReaFir.

name: ph 1.2 o2b b10 99 noise.wav
description: A sound that begins with oscillator set to noise which gives a wind like feel and then, as resonance is added, becomes more metallic and musical.

name: wind scupture.wav
description: Unique sculpture named "Imagines Eolinas Del Elqui" created by Mario Arenas Navarette. This "sound sculpture" uses the wind that blows from the Elqui valley to produce unique sound vibrations. It is located on the Elqui Dam in Chile. Recorded with a Sony Z1u HD camera in September 2006.

There is a compression. I changed the height to make it looks like someone walking in the wind.

name: GARCIN_Laura_2018_2019_Wind.wav

To create this sound, I mixed synthesis and real sounds. I used sound of a door, steps, and a keyboard. I put different effects like wahwah, reverberation and echo. I create a wind sound generating a white noise and putting wahwah on it. I wanted to create a windy environment with slamming doors and worrying steps.

name: Transformed wind chimes: Nature-Symphony 11
description: Nature-Symphony 11 (The Eternal Astronomer's gaze) — The original field recording (https://freesound.org/people/Philip_Goddard/sounds/699999/ ) had a lovely early spring fine breezy day quality about it, but this two-layer transformation of it is dramatically different! This is a real tough, challenging work, which would be riveting for those who are able to open to it, but undoubtedly repellent to the vast majority, who lack the requisite awareness and mental flexibility to cope with its ever-shifting harmonic clusters and the obsessive tone that shines out from the Galaxy, through all its dust clouds and other obscuring phenomena. It's a great wrench after the sweet and relatively unchallenging sound of Nature-Symphony 10 — but then for me the latter was my 'lightest' and least challenging Nature-Symphony so far, and for me perhaps the least satisfying — shall we say, 'just a little divertimento'. This one is on the other pole, as is my next upload here, Nature-Symphony 12 (Around the rim of the quivering volcano). They are both intense visionary pieces, as suggested by their titles. I myself was dumbfounded, when I idly put two differently speed-reduced copies of the original field recording into Audacity as layers, gave them the usual Nature-Symphony processing, and idly started playback before making expected adjustments; I was then riveted and had to listen to the end of the shorter (top) layer, where I just had to do a few minutes' work to get the piece to finish in a meaningful way. No further adjustments required. Mix-and-render and save — simple! Chimes used: 1. Music of the Spheres Gypsy Chimes, Mezzo and Soprano (both tuned to different modes on an Eastern European Gypsy scale) 2. Bamboo chimes, large and small set (rather indeterminate tuning, with a touch of whole-tone scale — bought cheaply at local store) I made the original field recording on 5 March 2013 beside the the Hunter's Path, high up on north side of the Teign Gorge, Drewsteignton, Devon, UK. Advisory This work is meant to sound rather distant, so I strongly recommend NOT turning the volume control higher than a sensible normal listening level. For extended sections a penetrating relatively high G is persistently sounding from the Gypsy Mezzo chime in the top layer, and this can be wearying and indeed somewhat harmful if you listen to this (especially repeatedly) at more than the intended level. The original recording taking place. The two bamboo chimes are on the left, and the two Gypsy chimes are on the right. Techie stuff: The recorder was Sony PCM-M10, with Røde DeadKitten furry windshield (original, more effective version). It was set up on a Velbon Mini tripod. Although I fairly quickly learned subsequently to avoid having recorders so close to the ground (distorts the frequency spectrum and tends to overemphasize lower parts of the frequency range), actually in this situation it was necessary to have the recorder really low down, where the wind was much lighter. Post-recording processing was to apply EQ in Audacity to correct for the muffling effect of the windshield — and then more recently stereo widening / sharpening-up using the VST plugin A1 Stereo Control (160% widening). To create this Nature-Symphony from it, I took two copies and used the 'change speed and pitch' effect in WavePad to reduce the speed to achieve the intended pitch reduction — top layer an octave lower, and bottom layer a minor seventh below that. Further processing then in Audacity: I used the OrilRiver VST plugin to apply a moderately back-of-cathedral acoustic. I allowed both layers to start at the same time, so they immediately start becoming more and more out of step with each other. Because the last 45 minutes of the bottom layer were not only left unused but contained its most thrilling activity, I saved that, with a strong inner nudging to add that to another processed field recording — and that quickly led to my creating Nature-Symphony 12 (next upload here). Please remember to give this recording a rating — Thank you!
